ygData.subject: New Website for Evolving Three-Dimensional Objects with CPPNs: EndlessForms.com

Content-type: text/plain;
	charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

Hello all-

I am happy to announce a website where you can interactively evolve 3D
objects with CPPNs (the encoding for HyperNEAT):

http://www.EndlessForms.com <http://www.EndlessForms.com>

Please try the site out and publish the interesting objects that you
discover. Doing so will help bolster the argument that CPPNs and other
encodings based on similar abstractions of developmental biology are a
powerful way to encode phenotypes.

I have been amazed by the sorts of images Picbreeder produced, but when I
show the images to biologists and other scientists a frequent response is
that they're "just" two-dimensional pictures and thus don't show that CPPNs
can produce interesting real-world (i.e. three-dimensional) forms. I never
felt that way, but it got me wondering whether we could evolve equally
compelling designs in three dimensions. To investigate that issue, a team of
us here at Cornell built EndlessForms.com, which enables us as a community
to explore the three-dimensional forms/objects/morphologies that CPPNs can
produce. 

Evolving objects on the site is also an intuitive way to understand how
mutation and crossover affect CPPN phenotypes.

The site also demonstrates how 3D objects can be automatically designed
without a knowledge of 3D-CAD software. That's especially useful now that 3D
printers are coming of age. We will soon add the ability to have any object
on the site 3D-printed in a variety of materials (e.g. silver, steel,
ceramic, etc.) and shipped to you.

As you'll see, we are heavily inspired by Picbreeder and utilized many of
its successful design choices. Thanks to the entire Picbreeder team for
coming up with so many great ideas and sharing them. Special thanks to Ken
Stanley and Jimmy Secretan for providing helpful suggestions for improving
earlier versions of EndlessForms. We are actively developing the site, so if
any of you have any feedback on how to improve it, please let me know.

Some of you may be interested in the technology behind the site. We utilize
new web standards, such as WebGL, that enable the rendering of 3D objects.
These technologies are brand new, so EndlessForms.com would not have been
technologically possible as recently as a year ago. EndlessForms.com is, to
our knowledge, one of the first sites on the internet that utilizes WebGL in
anything but a WebGL demo.

PS. Please help generate traffic to the site by sharing it with your
friends, posting it to Facebook, etc. The goal is to really see what CPPNs
can do by having as many people exploring the design space as possible!

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Postdoctoral Fellow
Hod Lipson's Creative Machines Laboratory
Cornell University
jeffclune@... <jeffclune@...>
www.msu.edu/~jclune



--B_3389432977_37455386
